Modern Coding Theory:
The Statistical Mechanics and Computer Science Point of View

Abstract

These are the notes for a set of lectures delivered by the two authors at the Les Houches Summer School on â€˜Complex Systemsâ€™ in July 2006. They provide an introduction to the basic concepts in modern (probabilistic) coding theory, highlighting connections with statistical mechanics. We also stress common concepts with other disciplines dealing with similar problems that can be generically referred to as â€˜large graphical modelsâ€™.

While most of the lectures are devoted to the classical channel coding problem over simple memoryless channels, we present a discussion of more complex channel models. We conclude with an overview of the main open challenges in the field.

1 Introduction and Outline

The last few years have witnessed an impressive convergence of interests between disciplines which are a priori well separated: coding and information theory, statistical inference, statistical mechanics (in particular, mean field disordered systems), as well as theoretical computer science. The underlying reason for this convergence is the importance of probabilistic models and/or probabilistic techniques in each of these domains. This has long been obvious in information theory [53], statistical mechanics [10], and statistical inference [45]. In the last few years it has also become apparent in coding theory and theoretical computer science. In the first case, the invention of Turbo codes [7] and the re-invention of Low-Density Parity-Check (LDPC) codes [30, 28] has motivated the use of random constructions for coding information in robust/compact ways [50]. In the second case (theoretical computer science) the relevance of randomized algorithms has steadily increased (see for instance [41]), thus motivating deep theoretical developments. A particularly important example is provided by the Monte Carlo Markov Chain method for counting and sampling random structures.

Given this common probabilistic background, some analogies between these disciplines is not very surprising nor is it particularly interesting. The key new ingredient which lifts the connections beyond some superficial commonalities is that one can name specific problems, questions, and results which lie at the intersection of these fields while being of central interest for each of them. The set of problems and techniques thus defined can be somewhat loosely named â€œtheory of large graphical models.â€ The typical setting is the following: a large set of random variables taking values in a finite (typically quite small) alphabet with a â€œlocalâ€ dependency structure; this local dependency structure is conveniently described by an appropriate graph.

In this lecture we shall use â€œmodernâ€ coding theory as an entry point to the domain. There are several motivations for this: (i)ğ‘–(i) theoretical work on this topic is strongly motivated by concrete and well-defined practical applications; (iâ€‹i)ğ‘–ğ‘–(ii) the probabilistic approach mentioned above has been quite successful and has substantially changed the field (whence the reference to modern coding theory); (iâ€‹iâ€‹i)ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–(iii) a sufficiently detailed picture exists illustrating the interplay among different view points.

We start in SectionÂ 2 with a brief outline of the (channel coding) problem. This allows us to introduce the standard definitions and terminology used in this field. In SectionÂ 3 we introduce ensembles of codes defined by sparse random graphs and discuss their most basic property â€“ the weight distribution. In SectionÂ 4 we phrase the decoding problem as an inference problem on a graph and consider the performance of the efficient (albeit in general suboptimal) message-passing decoder. We show how the performance of such a combination (sparse graph code and message-passing decoding) can be analyzed and we discuss the relationship of the performance under message-passing decoding to the performance of the optimal decoder. In SectionÂ 5 we briefly touch on some problems beyond coding, in order to show as similar concept emerge there. In particular, we discuss how message passing techniques can be successfully used in some families of counting/inference problems. In SectionÂ 6 we show that several of the simplifying assumptions (binary case, symmetry of channel, memoryless channels) are convenient in that they allow for a simple theory but are not really necessary. In particular, we discuss a simple channel with memory and we see how to proceed in the asymmetric case. Finally, we conclude in SectionÂ 7 with a few fundamental open problems.

To readers who would like to find current contributions on this topic we recommend the IEEE Transactions on Information Theory. A considerably more in-depth discussion can be found in the two upcoming books Information, Physics and Computation [36] and Modern Coding Theory [50]. Standard references on coding theory are [6, 9, 26] and very readable introductions to information theory can be found in [12, 20]. Other useful reference sources are the book by Nishimori [44] as well as the book by MacKay [29].

2 Background: The Channel Coding Problem

The central problem of communications is how to transmit information reliably through a noisy (and thus unreliable) communication channel. Coding theory aims at accomplishing this task by adding a properly designed redundancy to the transmitted message. This redundancy is then used at the receiver to reconstruct the original message despite the noise introduced by the channel.

2.1 The Problem

In order to model the situation described above we shall assume that the noise is random with some known distribution.111It is worth mentioning that an alternative approach would be to consider the noise as â€˜adversarialâ€™ (or worst case) under some constraint on its intensity. To keep things simple we shall assume that the communication channel admits as input binary symbols xâˆˆ{ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}ğ‘¥01x\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}, while the output belongs to some finite alphabet ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}. We denote the probability of observing the output yâˆˆğ’œğ‘¦ğ’œy\in{\cal A} given that the input was xâˆˆ{ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}ğ‘¥01x\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\} by Qâ€‹(y|x)ğ‘„conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥Q(y|x). The channel model is defined by the transition probability matrix

Q={Q(y|x):xâˆˆ{ğŸ¶,ğŸ·},yâˆˆğ’œ}.\displaystyle Q=\{Q(y|x):\,x\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\},\;y\in{\cal A}\}\,. (2.1)

Of course, the entries of this matrix must be non-negative and normalized in such a way that âˆ‘yQâ€‹(y|x)=1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘„conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥1\sum_{y}Q(y|x)=1.

It is convenient to have a few simple examples in mind. We refer to Fig.Â 1 for an illustration of the channel models which we introduce in the following three examples.

  • Example 1: The binary symmetric channel BSCâ€‹(p)BSCğ‘{\rm BSC}(p) is defined by letting ğ’œ={ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}ğ’œ01{\cal A}=\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\} and Qâ€‹(ğŸ¶|ğŸ¶)=Qâ€‹(ğŸ·|ğŸ·)=1âˆ’pğ‘„conditional00ğ‘„conditional111ğ‘Q({\tt 0}|{\tt 0})=Q({\tt 1}|{\tt 1})=1-p; the normalization then enforces Qâ€‹(ğŸ·|ğŸ¶)=Qâ€‹(ğŸ¶|ğŸ·)=pğ‘„conditional10ğ‘„conditional01ğ‘Q({\tt 1}|{\tt 0})=Q({\tt 0}|{\tt 1})=p. In words, the channel â€œflipsâ€ the input bit with probability pâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01p\in[0,1]. Since flips are introduced for each bit independently we say that the channel is memoryless. Except for an example in SectionÂ 6.2 all channels which we consider are memoryless.

  • Example 2: The binary erasure channel BECâ€‹(Ïµ)BECitalic-Ïµ{\rm BEC}(\epsilon) is defined by ğ’œ={ğŸ¶,ğŸ·,âˆ—}ğ’œ01âˆ—{\cal A}=\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1},\ast\} and Qâ€‹(ğŸ¶|ğŸ¶)=Qâ€‹(ğŸ·|ğŸ·)=1âˆ’Ïµğ‘„conditional00ğ‘„conditional111italic-ÏµQ({\tt 0}|{\tt 0})=Q({\tt 1}|{\tt 1})=1-\epsilon while Q(âˆ—|ğŸ¶)=Q(âˆ—|ğŸ·)=ÏµQ(\ast|{\tt 0})=Q(\ast|{\tt 1})=\epsilon. We invite the reader to write the transition probability matrix.

Since in each case the input is binary we speak of a binary-input channel. Since further in all models each input symbol is distorted independently from all other ones we say that the channels are memoryless. It is convenient to further restrict our attention to symmetric channels: this means that there is an involution on ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A} (i.e. a mapping Î¹:ğ’œâ†’ğ’œ:ğœ„â†’ğ’œğ’œ\iota:{\cal A}\to{\cal A} such that Î¹âˆ˜Î¹=1ğœ„ğœ„1\iota\circ\iota=1) so that Qâ€‹(y|ğŸ¶)=Qâ€‹(Î¹â€‹(y)|ğŸ·)ğ‘„conditionalğ‘¦0ğ‘„conditionalğœ„ğ‘¦1Q(y|{\tt 0})=Q(\iota(y)|{\tt 1}). This condition is satisfied by the first two examples above but not by the third one. To summarize these three properties one refers to such models as BMS channels.

In order to complete the problem description we need to formalize the information which is to be transmitted. We shall model this probabilistically as well and assume that the transmitter has an information source that provides an infinite stream of i.i.d. fair coins: {zi;i=0,1,2,â€¦}formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘–012â€¦\{z_{i};i=0,1,2,\dots\}, with ziâˆˆ{ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–01z_{i}\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\} uniformly at random. The goal is to reproduce this stream faithfully after communicating it over the noisy channel.

Let us stress that, despite its simplification, the present setting contains most of the crucial and challenges of the channel coding problem. Some of the many generalizations are described in SectionÂ 6.

2.2 Block Coding

The (general) coding strategy we shall consider here is block coding. It works as follows:

The flow chart describing this coding scheme is shown in Fig.Â 2. It is convenient to slightly modify the above scheme. Notice that, under the hypothesis that the encoder is injective, the codebook is in one-to-one correspondence with the source sequences. Since these are equiprobable, the transmitted codewords are equiprobable as well. We can therefore equivalently assume that the transmitter picks a codeword uniformly at random and transmits it. If, on the other hand, we are interested in the fraction of bits that we decode correctly then the exact mapping from information word to codeword does come into play. We shall ignore this somewhat subtle point in the sequel. Râ‰¡LN=1Nâ€‹log2â¡|â„­|.ğ‘…ğ¿ğ‘1ğ‘subscript2â„­\displaystyle R\equiv\frac{L}{N}=\frac{1}{N}\,\log_{2}|{\mathfrak{C}}|\,. (2.2)

Two fundamental performance parameters are the bit (or â€˜symbolâ€™) and block (or â€˜wordâ€™) error rates. The block error rate is the probability that the input codeword is not recovered correctly at the end of the process,

PBâ‰¡â„™â€‹{xÂ¯^â€‹(yÂ¯)â‰ xÂ¯}.subscriptPBâ„™^Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥\displaystyle{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}\equiv{\mathbb{P}}\left\{\widehat{\underline{x}}(\underline{y})\neq\underline{x}\right\}\,. (2.3)

Pbâ‰¡1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ„™â€‹{x^iâ€‹(yÂ¯)â‰ xi}.subscriptPb1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘â„™subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–Â¯ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\displaystyle{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}\equiv\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{P}}\left\{\widehat{x}_{i}(\underline{y})\neq x_{i}\right\}\,. (2.4)

It should not be too surprising that one can trade-off rate and error probability. We want to achieve a high rate and achieve a low probability of error. However, increasing the rate decreases the redundancy built into the codeword, thus inducing a higher error probability. The aim of coding theory is to choose the code â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}} and the decoding function xÂ¯^â€‹(â‹…)^Â¯ğ‘¥â‹…\widehat{\underline{x}}(\,\cdot\,) in a way to optimize this trade-off.

2.4 Conditional Entropy and Free Energy

As mentioned above, we are interested in understanding the properties of the (random) distribution Î¼â„­,yâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğœ‡â„­ğ‘¦â‹…\mu_{{\mathfrak{C}},y}(\,\cdot\,). One possible way of formalizing this idea is to consider the entropy of this distribution.

Let us recall that the (Shannon) entropy of a discrete random variable Xğ‘‹X (or, equivalently, of its distribution) quantifies, in a very precise sense, the â€˜uncertaintyâ€™ associated with Xğ‘‹X.444For a very readable account of information theory we recommend [12]. It is given by

Hâ€‹(X)=âˆ’âˆ‘xâ„™â€‹(x)â€‹logâ¡â„™â€‹(x).ğ»ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥â„™ğ‘¥â„™ğ‘¥\displaystyle H(X)=-\sum_{x}{\mathbb{P}}(x)\log{\mathbb{P}}(x)\,. (2.15)

For two random variables Xğ‘‹X and Yğ‘ŒY one defines the conditional entropy of Xğ‘‹X given Yğ‘ŒY as

Hâ€‹(X|Y)ğ»conditionalğ‘‹ğ‘Œ\displaystyle H(X|Y) =\displaystyle= âˆ’âˆ‘x,yâ„™â€‹(x,y)â€‹logâ¡â„™â€‹(x|y)=ğ”¼yâ€‹{âˆ’âˆ‘xâ„™â€‹(x|Y)â€‹logâ¡â„™â€‹(x|Y)}.subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦â„™ğ‘¥ğ‘¦â„™conditionalğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ”¼ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¥â„™conditionalğ‘¥ğ‘Œâ„™conditionalğ‘¥ğ‘Œ\displaystyle-\sum_{x,y}{\mathbb{P}}(x,y)\log{\mathbb{P}}(x|y)={\mathbb{E}}_{y}\left\{-\sum_{x}{\mathbb{P}}(x|Y)\log{\mathbb{P}}(x|Y)\right\}\,. (2.16)

This quantifies the remaining uncertainty about Xğ‘‹X when Yğ‘ŒY is observed.

Considering now the coding problem. Denote by XÂ¯Â¯ğ‘‹\underline{X} the (uniformly random) transmitted codeword and by YÂ¯Â¯ğ‘Œ\underline{Y} the channel output. 2.5 Shannon Theorem and Random Coding

As mentioned above, there exists an obvious tradeoff between high rate and low error probability. In his celebrated 1948 paper [53], Shannon derived the optimal error probability-vs-rate curve in the limit of large blocklengths. In particular, he proved that if the rate is larger than a particular threshold, then the error probability can be made arbitrarily small. The threshold depends on the channel and it is called the channel capacity. The capacity of a BMS channel (measured in bits per channel use) is given by the following elementary expression,

ğ™²â€‹(Q)=ğ™²ğ‘„absent\displaystyle{\tt C}(Q)= Hâ€‹(X)âˆ’Hâ€‹(X|Y)ğ»ğ‘‹ğ»conditionalğ‘‹ğ‘Œ\displaystyle H(X)-H(X|Y)
=\displaystyle= 1+âˆ‘yQâ€‹(y|ğŸ¶)â€‹log2â¡{Qâ€‹(y|ğŸ¶)Qâ€‹(y|ğŸ¶)+Qâ€‹(y|ğŸ·)}.1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘„conditionalğ‘¦0subscript2ğ‘„conditionalğ‘¦0ğ‘„conditionalğ‘¦0ğ‘„conditionalğ‘¦1\displaystyle 1+\sum_{y}Q(y|{\tt 0})\log_{2}\left\{\frac{Q(y|{\tt 0})}{Q(y|{\tt 0})+Q(y|{\tt 1})}\right\}\,.

For instance, the capacity of a BSCâ€‹(p)BSCğ‘{\rm BSC}(p) is ğ™²â€‹(p)=1âˆ’ğ”¥2â€‹(p)ğ™²ğ‘1subscriptğ”¥2ğ‘{\tt C}(p)=1-{\mathfrak{h}}_{2}(p), (where ğ”¥2â€‹(p)=âˆ’pâ€‹log2â¡pâˆ’(1âˆ’p)â€‹log2â¡(1âˆ’p)subscriptğ”¥2ğ‘ğ‘subscript2ğ‘1ğ‘subscript21ğ‘{\mathfrak{h}}_{2}(p)=-p\log_{2}p-(1-p)\log_{2}(1-p) is the entropy of a Bernoulli random variable of parameter pğ‘p) while the capacity of a BECâ€‹(Ïµ)BECitalic-Ïµ{\rm BEC}(\epsilon) is ğ™²â€‹(Ïµ)=1âˆ’Ïµğ™²italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ{\tt C}(\epsilon)=1-\epsilon. Theorem 2.1 (Channel Coding Theorem).

For any BMS channel with transition probability Qğ‘„Q and R<ğ™²â€‹(Q)ğ‘…ğ™²ğ‘„R<{\tt C}(Q) there exists a sequence of codes â„­Nsubscriptâ„­ğ‘{\mathfrak{C}}_{N} of increasing blocklength Nğ‘N and rate RNâ†’Râ†’subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘…R_{N}\to R whose block error probability PB(N)â†’0â†’superscriptsubscriptPBğ‘0{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}^{(N)}\to 0 as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty.

Vice versa, for any R>ğ™²â€‹(Q)ğ‘…ğ™²ğ‘„R>{\tt C}(Q) the block error probability of a code with rate at least Rğ‘…R is bounded away from 00.

The prove of the first part (â€˜achievabilityâ€™) is one of the first examples of the so-called â€˜probabilistic methodâ€™. In order to prove that there exists an object with a certain property (a code with small error probability), one constructs a probability distribution over all potential candidates (all codes of a certain blocklength and rate) and shows that a random element has the desired property with non-vanishing probability. The power of this approach is in the (meta-mathematical) observation that random constructions are often much easier to produce than explicit, deterministic ones.

The distribution over codes proposed by Shannon is usually referred to as the random code (or, Shannon) ensemble, and is particularly simple. One picks a code â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}} uniformly at random among all codes of blocklength Nğ‘N and rate Rğ‘…R. More explicitly, one picks 2Nâ€‹Rsuperscript2ğ‘ğ‘…2^{NR} codewords as uniformly random points in the hypercube {ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}Nsuperscript01ğ‘\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N}. This means that each codeword is a string of Nğ‘N fair coins xÂ¯(Î±)=(x1(Î±),â€¦,xN(Î±))superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ›¼subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ‘\underline{x}^{(\alpha)}=(x^{(\alpha)}_{1},\dots,x^{(\alpha)}_{N}) for555The reader might notice two imprecisions with this definition. First, 2Nâ€‹Rsuperscript2ğ‘ğ‘…2^{NR} is not necessarily an integer: one should rather use âŒˆ2Nâ€‹RâŒ‰superscript2ğ‘ğ‘…\lceil 2^{NR}\rceil codewords, but the difference is obviously negligible. Second, in contradiction with our definition, two codewords may coincide if they are independent. Again, only an exponentially small fraction of codewords will coincide and they can be neglected for all practical purposes. Î±=1,â€¦,2Nâ€‹Rğ›¼1â€¦superscript2ğ‘ğ‘…\alpha=1,\dots,2^{NR}.

The factor 2 of discrepancy can be recovered through a more careful argument.

Without entering into details, it is interesting to understand the basic reason for the discrepancy between the Shannon Theorem and the above argument. This is related to the geometry of high dimensional spaces. Let us assume for simplicity that the minimum distance between any two codewords in â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}} is at least Nâ€‹(Î´GVâ€‹(R)âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘subscriptğ›¿GVğ‘…ğœ€N(\delta_{\rm GV}(R)-\varepsilon). In a given random code, this is the case for most codeword pairs. We can then eliminate the pairs that do not satisfy this constraint, thus modifying the code rate in a negligible way (this procedure is called expurgation). The resulting code will have minimum distance (the minimum distance among any two codewords in â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}}) dâ€‹(â„­)â‰ˆNâ€‹Î´GVâ€‹(R)ğ‘‘â„­ğ‘subscriptğ›¿GVğ‘…d({\mathfrak{C}})\approx N\delta_{\rm GV}(R).

Imagine that we use such a code to communicate through a BSC and that exactly nğ‘›n bits are flipped. By the triangular inequality, as long as n<dâ€‹(â„­)/2ğ‘›ğ‘‘â„­2n<d({\mathfrak{C}})/2, the word MAP decoder will recover the transmitted message for all error patterns. If on the other hand n>dâ€‹(â„­)/2ğ‘›ğ‘‘â„­2n>d({\mathfrak{C}})/2, there are error patterns involving nğ‘›n bits such that the word-MAP decoder does not return the transmitted codeword. If for instance there exists a single codeword xÂ¯(1)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥1\underline{x}^{(1)} at distance dâ€‹(â„­)=2â€‹nâˆ’1ğ‘‘â„­2ğ‘›1d({\mathfrak{C}})=2n-1 from xÂ¯(0)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥0\underline{x}^{(0)}, any pattern involving nğ‘›n out of the 2â€‹nâˆ’12ğ‘›12n-1 such that xi(0)â‰ xi(1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1x_{i}^{(0)}\neq x_{i}^{(1)}, will induce a decoding error. However, it might well be that most error patterns with the same number of errors can be corrected.

Shannonâ€™s Theorem points out that this is indeed the case until the number of bits flipped by the channel is roughly equal to the minimum distance dâ€‹(â„­)ğ‘‘â„­d({\mathfrak{C}}).

3 Sparse Graph Codes

Shannonâ€™s Theorem provides a randomized construction to find a code with â€˜essentially optimalâ€™ rate vs error probability tradeoff. In practice, however, one cannot use random codes for communications. Just storing the code â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}} requires a memory which grows exponentially in the blocklength. In the same vein the optimal decoding procedure requires an exponentially increasing effort. On the other hand, we can not use very short codes since their performance is not very good. To see this assume that we transmit over the BSC with parameter pğ‘p. If the blocklength is Nğ‘N then the standard deviation of the number of errors contained in a block is Nâ€‹pâ€‹(1âˆ’p)ğ‘ğ‘1ğ‘\sqrt{Np(1-p)}. Unless this quantity is very small compared to Nâ€‹pğ‘ğ‘Np we have to either over-provision the error correcting capability of the code so as to deal with the occasionally large number of errors, waisting transmission rate most of the time, or we dimension the code for the typical case, but then we will not be able to decode when the number of errors is larger than the average. This means that short codes are either inefficient or unreliable (or both).

The general strategy for tackling this problem is to introduce more structure in the code definition, and to hope that such structure can be exploited for the encoding and the decoding. In the next section we shall describe a way of introducing structure that, while preserving Shannonâ€™s idea of random codes, opens the way to efficient encoding/decoding.

There are two main ingredients that make modern coding work and the two are tightly connected. The first important ingredient is to use codes which can be described by local constraints only. The second ingredient is to use a local algorithm instead of an high complexity global one (namely symbol MAP or word MAP decoding). In this section we describe the first component.

3.1 Linear Codes

One of the simplest forms of structure consists in requiring â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}} to be a linear subspace of {ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}Nsuperscript01ğ‘\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N}. One speaks then of a linear code. For specifying such a code it is not necessary to list all the codewords. In fact, any linear space can be seen as the kernel of a matrix:

â„­={xÂ¯âˆˆ{ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}N:â„â€‹xÂ¯=ğŸ¶Â¯},â„­conditional-setÂ¯ğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘â„Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯0\displaystyle{\mathfrak{C}}=\left\{\underline{x}\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N}:\;{\mathbb{H}}\underline{x}=\underline{\tt 0}\right\}\,, (3.1)

where the matrix vector multiplication is assumed to be performed modulo 222. The matrix â„â„{\mathbb{H}} is called the parity-check matrix. It has Nğ‘N columns and we let M<Nğ‘€ğ‘M<N denote its number of rows. Without loss of generality we can assume â„â„{\mathbb{H}} to have maximum rank Mğ‘€M. As a consequence, â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}} is a linear space of dimension Nâˆ’Mğ‘ğ‘€N-M. The rate of â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}} is

R=1âˆ’MN.ğ‘…1ğ‘€ğ‘\displaystyle R=1-\frac{M}{N}\,. (3.2)

The ağ‘a-th line in â„â€‹xÂ¯=ğŸ¶Â¯â„Â¯ğ‘¥Â¯0{\mathbb{H}}\underline{x}=\underline{\tt 0} has the form (here and below âŠ•direct-sum\oplus denotes modulo 222 addition)

It is called a parity check.

The parity-check matrix is conveniently represented through a factor graph (also called Tanner graph). This is a bipartite graph including two types of nodes: Mğ‘€M function nodes (corresponding to the rows of â„â„{\mathbb{H}}, or the parity-check equations) and Nğ‘N variable nodes (for the columns of â„â„{\mathbb{H}}, or the variables). Edges are drawn whenever the corresponding entry in â„â„{\mathbb{H}} is non-vanishing.

In the following we shall use indices i,j,â€¦ğ‘–ğ‘—â€¦i,j,\dots for variable nodes and a,b,â€¦ğ‘ğ‘â€¦a,b,\dots for check nodes. We shall further denote by âˆ‚iğ‘–\partial i (respectively, âˆ‚ağ‘\partial a) the set of nodes that are adjacent to variable node iğ‘–i (to factor node ağ‘a).

Remarkably, introducing the linear space structure does not deteriorate the performances of the resulting code. Let us introduce Shannonâ€™s parity-check ensemble: it is defined by letting the parity-check matrix â„â„{\mathbb{H}} be a uniformly random matrix with the prescribed dimensions. Explicitly, each of the Nâ€‹Mğ‘ğ‘€NM entries Haâ€‹isubscriptğ»ğ‘ğ‘–H_{ai} is an independent Bernoulli random variable of mean 1/2121/2. Probabilistic arguments similar to the ones for the random code ensemble can be developed for the random parity-check ensemble. The conclusion is that random codes from this ensemble allow to communicate with arbitrarily small block error probability at any rate R<ğ™²â€‹(Q)ğ‘…ğ™²ğ‘„R<{\tt C}(Q), where ğ™²â€‹(Q)ğ™²ğ‘„{\tt C}(Q) is the capacity of the given BMS channel.

Unfortunately, linearity is not sufficient to guarantee that a code admits a low-complexity decoding algorithm. In particular, the algorithm which we discuss in the sequel works well only for codes that can be represented by a sparse parity-check matrix â„â„{\mathbb{H}} (i.e. a parity check matrix with Oâ€‹(N)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(N) non-vanishing entries). Notice that a given code â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}} has more than one representation of the form (3.1). A priori one could hope that, given a uniformly random matrix â„â„{\mathbb{H}}, a new matrix â„â€²superscriptâ„â€²{\mathbb{H}}^{\prime} could be built such that â„â€²superscriptâ„â€²{\mathbb{H}}^{\prime} is sparse and that its null space coincides with the one of â„â„{\mathbb{H}}. This would provide a sparse representation of â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}}. Unfortunately, this is the case only for a vanishing fraction of matrices â„â„{\mathbb{H}}, as shown by the exercise below.

  • Exercise 2: Consider a linear code â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}}, with blocklength Nğ‘N, and dimension Nâˆ’Mğ‘ğ‘€N-M (as a linear space). Prove the following sequence of arguments.

    • (iâ€‹iâ€‹i)ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–(iii)

With an abuse of language in the following we shall sometimes use the term â€˜codeâ€™ to denote a pair code/parity-check matrix.

3.2 Low-Density Parity-Check Codes

Further structure can be introduced by restricting the ensemble of parity-check matrices. Low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes are codes that have at least one sparse parity-check matrix.

Rather than considering the most general case let us limit ourselves to a particularly simple family of LDPC ensembles, originally introduced by Robert Gallager [19]. We call them â€˜regularâ€™ ensembles. An element in this family is characterized by the blocklength Nğ‘N and two integer numbers kğ‘˜k and lğ‘™l, with k>lğ‘˜ğ‘™k>l. We shall therefore refer to it as the (k,l)ğ‘˜ğ‘™(k,l) regular ensemble). In order to construct a random Tanner graph from this ensemble, one proceeds as follows:

  1. 1.

    Draw Nğ‘N variable nodes, each attached to lğ‘™l half-edges and M=Nâ€‹l/kğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘˜M=Nl/k (we neglect here the possibility of Nâ€‹l/kğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘˜Nl/k not being an integer) check nodes, each with kğ‘˜k half edges.

  2. 2.

    Use an arbitrary convention to label the half edges form 111 to Nâ€‹lğ‘ğ‘™Nl, both on the variable node side as well as the check node side (note that this requires that Mâ€‹k=Nâ€‹lğ‘€ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘™Mk=Nl).

  3. 3.

    Choose a permutation Ï€ğœ‹\pi uniformly at random among all permutations over Nâ€‹lğ‘ğ‘™Nl objects, and connect half edges accordingly.

Notice that the above procedure may give rise to multiple edges. Typically there will be Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) multiple edges in a graph constructed as described. These can be eliminated easily without effecting the performance substantially. From the analytical point of view, a simple choice consists in eliminating all the edges (i,a)ğ‘–ğ‘(i,a) if (i,a)ğ‘–ğ‘(i,a) occurs an even number of times, and replacing them by a single occurrence (i,a)ğ‘–ğ‘(i,a) if it occurs an odd number of times.

Neglecting multiple occurrences (and the way to resolve them), the parity-check matrix corresponding to the graph constructed in this way does include kğ‘˜k ones per row and lğ‘™l ones per column. In the sequel we will keep lğ‘™l and kğ‘˜k fixed and consider the behavior of the ensemble as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty. This implies that the matrix has only Oâ€‹(N)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(N) non-vanishing entries. The matrix is sparse.

For practical purposes it is important to maximize the rate at which such codes enable one to communicate with vanishing error probability. To achieve this goal, several more complex ensembles have been introduced. As an example, one simple idea is to consider a generic row/column weight distribution (the weight being the number of non-zero elements), cf. Fig.Â 6 for an illustration. Such ensembles are usually referred to as â€˜irregularâ€™, and were introduced in [27].

3.3 Weight Enumerator

As we saw in SectionÂ 2.5, the reason of the good performance of Shannon ensemble (having vanishing block error probability at rates arbitrarily close to the capacity), can be traced back to its minimum distance properties. This is indeed only a partial explanation (as we saw errors could be corrected well beyond half its minimum distance). It is nevertheless instructive and useful to understand the geometrical structure (and in particular the minimum distance properties) of typical codes from the LDPC ensembles defined above.

Let us start by noticing that, for linear codes, the distance enumerator does not depend upon the reference codeword. Let us finally comment on the relation between distance enumerator and the Franz-Parisi potential [18], introduced in the study of glassy systems. To be more specific, the weight enumerator can be seen as a special case of the Franz-Parisi potential. It is sufficient to take as Boltzmann distribution the uniform measure over codewords of a linear code â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}}. Then the restricted partition function is just the distance enumerator with respect to the reference codeword, which indeed does not depend on it.

4 The Decoding Problem for Sparse Graph Codes

As we have already seen, MAP decoding requires computing either marginals or the mode of the conditional distribution of xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} being the channel input given output yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y}. In the case of LDPC codes the posterior probability distribution factorizes according to underlying factor graph GğºG:

Î¼â„­,yâ€‹(xÂ¯)=1Zâ€‹(â„­,y)â€‹âˆi=1NQâ€‹(yi|xi)â€‹âˆa=1Mğ•€â€‹(xi1â€‹(a)âŠ•â‹¯âŠ•xikâ€‹(a)=ğŸ¶).subscriptğœ‡â„­ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥1ğ‘â„­ğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘ğ‘„conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘1ğ‘€ğ•€direct-sumsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘–1ğ‘â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘0\displaystyle\mu_{{\mathfrak{C}},y}(\underline{x})=\frac{1}{Z({\mathfrak{C}},y)}\,\prod_{i=1}^{N}Q(y_{i}|x_{i})\,\prod_{a=1}^{M}{\mathbb{I}}(x_{i_{1}(a)}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{i_{k}(a)}={\tt 0})\,. (4.1)

Here (i1â€‹(a),â€¦,ikâ€‹(a))subscriptğ‘–1ğ‘â€¦subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘(i_{1}(a),\dots,i_{k}(a)) denotes the set of variable indices involved in the ağ‘a-th parity check (i.e., the non-zero entries in the ağ‘a-th row of the parity-check matrix â„â„{\mathbb{H}}). In the language of spin models, the terms Qâ€‹(yi|xi)ğ‘„conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–Q(y_{i}|x_{i}) correspond to an external random field. The factors ğ•€â€‹(xi1â€‹(a)âŠ•â‹¯âŠ•xikâ€‹(a)=ğŸ¶)ğ•€direct-sumsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘–1ğ‘â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘0{\mathbb{I}}(x_{i_{1}(a)}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{i_{k}(a)}={\tt 0}) can instead be regarded as hard core kğ‘˜k-spins interactions. Under the mapping Ïƒi=(âˆ’1)xisubscriptğœğ‘–superscript1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\sigma_{i}=(-1)^{x_{i}}, such interactions depend on the spins through the product Ïƒi1â€‹(a)â€‹â‹¯â€‹Ïƒikâ€‹(a)subscriptğœsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘â‹¯subscriptğœsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘\sigma_{i_{1}(a)}\cdots\sigma_{i_{k}(a)}. The model (4.1) maps therefore onto a kğ‘˜k-spin model with random field.

For MAP decoding, minimum distance properties of the code play a crucial role in determining the performances. We investigated such properties in the previous section. Unfortunately, there is no known way of implementing MAP decoding efficiently. In this section we discuss two decoding algorithms that exploit the sparseness of the factor graph to achieve efficient decoding. Although such strategies are sub-optimal with respect to word (or symbol) MAP decoding, the graphical structure can itself be optimized, leading to state-of-the-art performances.

After briefly discussing bit-flipping decoding, most of this section will be devoted to message passing that is the approach most used in practice. Remarkably, both bit flipping as well as message passing are closely related to statistical mechanics.

4.1 Bit Flipping

For the sake of simplicity, let us assume that communication takes place over a binary symmetric channel. We receive the message yÂ¯âˆˆ{ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}NÂ¯ğ‘¦superscript01ğ‘\underline{y}\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N} and try to find the transmitted codeword xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} as follows:

  1. Bit-flipping decoder

  2. 0.

    Set xÂ¯â€‹(0)=yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥0Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{x}(0)=\underline{y}.

  3. 1.

    Find a bit belonging to more unsatisfied than satisfied parity checks.

  4. 2.

    If such a bit exists, flip it: xiâ€‹(t+1)=xiâ€‹(t)âŠ•ğŸ·subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡1direct-sumsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡1x_{i}(t+1)=x_{i}(t)\oplus{\tt 1}. Keep the other bits: xjâ€‹(t+1)=xjâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘¡x_{j}(t+1)=x_{j}(t) for all jâ‰ iğ‘—ğ‘–j\neq i.
    If there is no such bit, return xÂ¯â€‹(t)Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\underline{x}(t) and halt.

  5. 3.

    Repeat steps 1 and 2.

The bit to be flipped is usually chosen uniformly at random among the ones satisfying the condition at step 1. However this is irrelevant for the analysis below.

In order to monitor the bit-flipping algorithm, it is useful to introduce the function:

Uâ€‹(t)â‰¡#â€‹{Â parity-check equations not satisfied byÂ xÂ¯â€‹(t)Â }.ğ‘ˆğ‘¡#Â parity-check equations not satisfied byÂ xÂ¯(t)Â \displaystyle U(t)\equiv\#\left\{\mbox{ parity-check equations not satisfied by $\underline{x}(t)$\, }\right\}\,. (4.2)

This is a non-negative integer, and if Uâ€‹(t)=0ğ‘ˆğ‘¡0U(t)=0 the algorithm is halted and it outputs xÂ¯â€‹(t)Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\underline{x}(t). Furthermore, Uâ€‹(t)ğ‘ˆğ‘¡U(t) cannot be larger than the number of parity checks Mğ‘€M and decreases (by at least one) at each cycle. Therefore, the algorithm complexity is Oâ€‹(N)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(N) (this is a commonly regarded as the ultimate goal for many communication problems).

It remains to be seen if the output of the bit-flipping algorithm is related to the transmitted codeword. In Fig.Â 8 we present the results of a numerical experiment. We considered the (5,10)510(5,10) regular ensemble and generated about 100010001000 random code and channel realizations for each value of the noise level pğ‘p in some mesh. Then, we applied the above algorithm and traced the fraction of successfully decoded blocks, as well as the residual energy Uâˆ—=Uâ€‹(tâˆ—)subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘¡U_{*}=U(t_{*}), where tâˆ—subscriptğ‘¡t_{*} is the total number of iterations of the algorithm. The data suggests that bit-flipping is able to overcome a finite noise level: it recovers the original message with high probability when less than about 2.5%percent2.52.5\% of the bits are corrupted by the channel. Furthermore, the curves for the block error probability PBbfsuperscriptsubscriptPBbf{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}^{\rm bf} under bit-flipping decoding become steeper and steeper as the system size is increased. It is natural to conjecture that asymptotically, a phase transition takes place at a well defined noise level pbfsubscriptğ‘bfp_{\rm bf}: PBbfâ†’0â†’superscriptsubscriptPBbf0{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}^{\rm bf}\to 0 for p<pbfğ‘subscriptğ‘bfp<p_{\rm bf} and PBbfâ†’1â†’superscriptsubscriptPBbf1{\rm P}_{{\rm B}}^{\rm bf}\to 1 for p>pbfğ‘subscriptğ‘bfp>p_{\rm bf}. Numerically pbf=0.025Â±0.005subscriptğ‘bfplus-or-minus0.0250.005p_{\rm bf}=0.025\pm 0.005.

This threshold can be compared with the one for word MAP decoding, that we will call pcsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm c}: The bounds in [60] state that 0.108188â‰¤pcâ‰¤0.1091610.108188subscriptğ‘c0.1091610.108188\leq p_{\rm c}\leq 0.109161 for the (5,10)510(5,10) ensemble, while a statistical mechanics calculation yields pcâ‰ˆ0.1091subscriptğ‘c0.1091p_{\rm c}\approx 0.1091. Bit-flipping is significantly sub-optimal, but it is still surprisingly good, given the extreme simplicity of the algorithm.

These numerical findings can be confirmed rigorously [55].

Theorem 4.1.

Consider a regular (l,k)ğ‘™ğ‘˜(l,k) LDPC ensemble and let â„­â„­{\mathfrak{C}} be chosen uniformly at random from the ensemble. If lâ‰¥5ğ‘™5l\geq 5 then there exists Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 such that, with high probability, Bit-flipping is able to correct any pattern of at most Nâ€‹Îµğ‘ğœ€N\varepsilon errors produced by a binary symmetric channel.

Given a generic word xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} (i.e., a length Nğ‘N binary string that is not necessarily a codeword), let us denote, with a slight abuse of notation, by Uâ€‹(xÂ¯)ğ‘ˆÂ¯ğ‘¥U(\underline{x}) the number of parity-check equations that are not satisfied by xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x}. The above result, together with the weight enumerator calculation in the previous section, suggests the following picture of the function Uâ€‹(xÂ¯)ğ‘ˆÂ¯ğ‘¥U(\underline{x}). If xÂ¯(0)âˆˆâ„­superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥0â„­\underline{x}^{(0)}\in{\mathfrak{C}}, than Uâ€‹(xÂ¯(0))=0ğ‘ˆsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥00U(\underline{x}^{(0)})=0. Moving away from xÂ¯(0)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥0\underline{x}^{(0)}, Uâ€‹(xÂ¯)ğ‘ˆÂ¯ğ‘¥U(\underline{x}) will become strictly positive. However as long as dâ€‹(xÂ¯(0),xÂ¯)ğ‘‘superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥0Â¯ğ‘¥d(\underline{x}^{(0)},\underline{x}) is small enough, Uâ€‹(xÂ¯)ğ‘ˆÂ¯ğ‘¥U(\underline{x}) does not have any local minimum distinct from xÂ¯(0)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥0\underline{x}^{(0)}. A greedy procedure with a starting point within such a Hamming radius is able to reconstruct xÂ¯(0)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥0\underline{x}^{(0)}. As we move further away, Uâ€‹(xÂ¯)ğ‘ˆÂ¯ğ‘¥U(\underline{x}) stays positive (no other codewords are encountered) but local minima start to appear. Bit flipping gets trapped in such minima. Finally, for dâ€‹(xÂ¯(0),xÂ¯)â‰¥Nâ€‹Ï‰âˆ—ğ‘‘superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥0Â¯ğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğœ”d(\underline{x}^{(0)},\underline{x})\geq N\omega_{*} new codewords, i.e., minima with Uâ€‹(xÂ¯)=0ğ‘ˆÂ¯ğ‘¥0U(\underline{x})=0, are encountered.

4.2 Message Passing

Message-passing algorithms are iterative and have low complexity. Unlike the bit-flipping procedure in the previous section, the basic variables are now associated to directed edges in the factor graph. More precisely, for each edge (i,a)ğ‘–ğ‘(i,a) (corresponding to a non-zero entry in the parity-check matrix at row ağ‘a and column iğ‘–i), we introduce two messages Î½iâ†’asubscriptğœˆâ†’ğ‘–ğ‘\nu_{i\to a} and Î½^aâ†’isubscript^ğœˆâ†’ğ‘ğ‘–\widehat{\nu}_{a\to i}. Messages are elements of some set (the message alphabet) that we shall denote by ğ–¬ğ–¬{\sf M}. Depending on the specific algorithm, ğ–¬ğ–¬{\sf M} can have finite cardinality, or be infinite, for instance ğ–¬=â„ğ–¬â„{\sf M}={\mathbb{R}}. Since the algorithm is iterative, it is convenient to introduce a time index t=0,1,2,â€¦ğ‘¡012â€¦t=0,1,2,\dots and label the messages with the time at which they are updated: Î½iâ†’a(t)subscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡â†’ğ‘–ğ‘\nu^{(t)}_{i\to a} and Î½^aâ†’i(t)subscriptsuperscript^ğœˆğ‘¡â†’ğ‘ğ‘–\widehat{\nu}^{(t)}_{a\to i} (but we will sometimes drop the label below).

The defining property of message-passing algorithms is that the message flowing from node uğ‘¢u to vğ‘£v at a given time is a function of messages entering uğ‘¢u from nodes wğ‘¤w distinct from vğ‘£v at the previous time step. Formally, the algorithm is defined in terms of two sets of functions Î¦iâ†’aâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptÎ¦â†’ğ‘–ğ‘â‹…\Phi_{i\to a}(\,\cdot\,), Î¨aâ†’iâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptÎ¨â†’ğ‘ğ‘–â‹…\Psi_{a\to i}(\,\cdot\,), that define the update operations at variable and function nodes as follows

Î½iâ†’a(t+1)=Î¦iâ†’aâ€‹({Î½^bâ†’i(t);bâˆˆâˆ‚i\a};yi),Î½^aâ†’i(t)=Î¨aâ†’iâ€‹({Î½jâ†’a(t);jâˆˆâˆ‚a\i}).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğœˆâ†’ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¡1subscriptÎ¦â†’ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptsuperscript^ğœˆğ‘¡â†’ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘\ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^ğœˆâ†’ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptÎ¨â†’ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡â†’ğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘—\ğ‘ğ‘–\displaystyle\nu_{i\to a}^{(t+1)}=\Phi_{i\to a}(\{\widehat{\nu}^{(t)}_{b\to i};b\in\partial i\backslash a\};y_{i})\,,\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\widehat{\nu}_{a\to i}^{(t)}=\Psi_{a\to i}(\{\nu^{(t)}_{j\to a};j\in\partial a\backslash i\})\,. (4.3)

Notice that messages are updated in parallel and that the time counter is incremented only at variable nodes. Alternative scheduling schemes can be considered but we will stick to this for the sake of simplicity. After a pre-established number of iterations, the transmitted bits are estimated using all the messages incoming at the corresponding nodes. More precisely, the estimate at function iğ‘–i is defined through a new function

4.3 Correctness of Belief Propagation on Trees

Î¼iâ†’aâ€‹(xi)subscriptğœ‡â†’ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\displaystyle\mu_{i\to a}(x_{i}) âˆproportional-to\displaystyle\propto Qâ€‹(yi|xi)â€‹âˆbâˆˆâˆ‚i\aÎ¼^bâ†’iâ€‹(xi),ğ‘„conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptproductğ‘\ğ‘–ğ‘subscript^ğœ‡â†’ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\displaystyle Q(y_{i}|x_{i})\!\prod_{b\in\partial i\backslash a}\widehat{\mu}_{b\to i}(x_{i})\,, (4.16)
Î¼^aâ†’iâ€‹(xi)subscript^ğœ‡â†’ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\displaystyle\widehat{\mu}_{a\to i}(x_{i}) âˆproportional-to\displaystyle\propto âˆ‘{xj}ğ•€â€‹(xiâŠ•xj1âŠ•â‹¯âŠ•xjkâˆ’1=ğŸ¶)â€‹âˆjâˆˆâˆ‚a\iÎ¼jâ†’aâ€‹(xj),subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ•€direct-sumsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘—1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘—ğ‘˜10subscriptproductğ‘—\ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡â†’ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—\displaystyle\sum_{\{x_{j}\}}{\mathbb{I}}(x_{i}\oplus x_{j_{1}}\oplus\cdots\oplus x_{j_{k-1}}={\tt 0})\prod_{j\in\partial a\backslash i}\mu_{j\to a}(x_{j})\,, (4.17)

which coincide, apart from the time index, with the BP recursion (4.5), (4.6). That such recursions converges to {Î¼iâ†’aâ€‹(xi),Î¼^aâ†’iâ€‹(xi)}subscriptğœ‡â†’ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscript^ğœ‡â†’ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\{\mu_{i\to a}(x_{i}),\widehat{\mu}_{a\to i}(x_{i})\} follows by induction over the tree depth.

In statistical mechanics equations similar to (4.16), (4.17) are often written as recursions on the constrained partition function. They allow to solve exactly models on trees. However they have been often applied as mean-field approximation to statistical models on non-tree graphs. This is often referred to as the Bethe-Peierls approximation [8].

The Bethe approximation presents several advantages with respect to â€˜naive-mean fieldâ€™ [61] (that amounts to writing â€˜self-consistencyâ€™ equations for expectations over single degrees of freedom). It retains correlations among degrees of freedom that interact directly, and is exact on some non-empty graph (trees). It is often asymptotically (in the large size limit) exact on locally tree-like graphs. Finally, it is quantitatively more accurate for non-tree like graphs and offers a much richer modeling palette.

Within the theory of disordered systems (especially, glass models on sparse random graphs), Eqs.Â (4.16) and (4.17) are also referred to as the cavity equations. With respect to Bethe-Peierls, the cavity approach includes a hierarchy of (â€˜replica symmetry breakingâ€™) refinements of such equations that aim at capturing long range correlations [37]. This will briefly described in Section 5.

We should finally mention that several improvements over Bethe approximation have been developed within statistical physics. Among them, Kikuchiâ€™s cluster variational method [24] is worth mentioning since it motivated the development of a â€˜generalized belief propagationâ€™ algorithm, which spurred a lot of interest within the artificial intelligence community [61].

4.4 Density Evolution

Although BP converges to the exact marginals on tree graphs, this says little about its performances on practical codes such as the LDPC ensembles introduced in SectionÂ 3. Fortunately, a rather precise picture on the performance of LDPC ensembles can be derived in the large blocklength limit Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty. The basic reason for this is that the corresponding random factor graph is locally tree-like with high probability if we consider large blocklengths.

Before elaborating on this point, notice that the performance under BP decoding (e.g., the bit error rate) is independent on the transmitted codeword. For the sake of analysis, we shall hereafter assume that the all-zero codeword ğŸ¶Â¯Â¯0\underline{\tt 0} has been transmitted.

Consider a factor graph GğºG and let (i,a)ğ‘–ğ‘(i,a) be one of its edges. Consider the message Î½iâ†’a(t)subscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡â†’ğ‘–ğ‘\nu^{(t)}_{i\to a} sent by the BP decoder in iteration tğ‘¡t along edge (i,a)ğ‘–ğ‘(i,a). A considerable amount of information is contained in the distribution of Î½iâ†’a(t)subscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡â†’ğ‘–ğ‘\nu^{(t)}_{i\to a} with respect to the channel realization, as well as in the analogous distribution for Î½^aâ†’i(t)subscriptsuperscript^ğœˆğ‘¡â†’ğ‘ğ‘–\widehat{\nu}^{(t)}_{a\to i}. To see this, note that under the all-zero codeword assumption, the bit error rate after tğ‘¡t iterations is given by

Pb(t)=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nâ„™â€‹{Î¦iâ€‹({Î½^bâ†’i(t);bâˆˆâˆ‚i};yi)â‰ ğŸ¶}.superscriptsubscriptPbğ‘¡1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›â„™subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^ğœˆâ†’ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–0\displaystyle{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\mathbb{P}}\left\{\Phi_{i}(\{\widehat{\nu}_{b\to i}^{(t)};b\in\partial i\};y_{i})\neq{\tt 0}\right\}\,. (4.18)

Therefore, if the messages Î½^bâ†’i(t)superscriptsubscript^ğœˆâ†’ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡\widehat{\nu}_{b\to i}^{(t)} are independent, then the bit error probability is determined by the distribution of Î½^aâ†’i(t)subscriptsuperscript^ğœˆğ‘¡â†’ğ‘ğ‘–\widehat{\nu}^{(t)}_{a\to i}.

Rather than considering one particular graph (code) and a specific edge, it is much simpler to take the average over all edges and all graph realizations. We thus consider the distribution ğ–ºt(N)â€‹(â‹…)superscriptsubscriptğ–ºğ‘¡ğ‘â‹…{\sf a}_{t}^{(N)}(\,\cdot\,) of Î½iâ†’a(t)subscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡â†’ğ‘–ğ‘\nu^{(t)}_{i\to a} with respect to the channel, the edges, and the graph realization. While this is still a quite difficult object to study rigorously, it is on the other hand possible to characterize its large blocklength limit ğ–ºtâ€‹(â‹…)=limNğ–ºt(N)â€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ–ºğ‘¡â‹…subscriptğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ–ºğ‘¡ğ‘â‹…{\sf a}_{t}(\,\cdot\,)=\lim_{N}{\sf a}_{t}^{(N)}(\,\cdot\,). This distribution satisfies a simple recursion.

It is convenient to introduce the directed neighborhood of radius rğ‘Ÿr of the directed edge iâ†’aâ†’ğ‘–ğ‘i\to a in GğºG, call it ğ–¡iâ†’aâ€‹(r;G)subscriptğ–¡â†’ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğº{\sf B}_{i\to a}(r;G). It includes as well all the function nodes connected only to the above specified variable nodes. If Fğ¹F is the factor graph of a random code from the (k,l)ğ‘˜ğ‘™(k,l) LDPC ensemble, then ğ–¡iâ†’aâ€‹(r;F)subscriptğ–¡â†’ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ¹{\sf B}_{i\to a}(r;F) is with high probability a depth-rğ‘Ÿr regular tree with degree lğ‘™l at variable nodes and degree kğ‘˜k at check nodes (as in Fig.Â 13 where l=2ğ‘™2l=2 and k=3ğ‘˜3k=3). At any finite radius rğ‘Ÿr, about cr/Nsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘c^{r}/N vertices have been visited (here c=(kâˆ’1)â€‹(lâˆ’1)ğ‘ğ‘˜1ğ‘™1c=(k-1)(l-1)). The probability that two out of a party of nğ‘›n peoples were born on the same day of the year, scales like n2/Nsuperscriptğ‘›2ğ‘n^{2}/N for n2â‰ªNmuch-less-thansuperscriptğ‘›2ğ‘n^{2}\ll N (Nğ‘N is here the number of days in a year). This is equivalent to râ‰ƒ12â€‹logcâ¡Nsimilar-to-or-equalsğ‘Ÿ12subscriptğ‘ğ‘r\simeq\frac{1}{2}\log_{c}N.

4.5 The Belief Propagation Threshold

Density evolution would not be such an useful tool if it could not be simulated efficiently. The idea is to estimate numerically the distributions of the density evolution variables {h(t),u(t)}superscriptâ„ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¢ğ‘¡\{h^{(t)},u^{(t)}\}. As already discussed this gives access to a number of statistics on BP decoding, such as the bit error rate Pb(t)superscriptsubscriptPbğ‘¡{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)} after tğ‘¡t iterations in the large blocklength limit.

A possible approach consists in representing the distributions by samples of some fixed size. Within statistical physics this is sometimes called the population dynamics algorithm (and made its first appearance in the study of the localization transition on Cayley trees [46]). Although there exist more efficient alternatives in the coding context (mainly based on Fourier transform, see [49, 48]), we shall describe population dynamics because it is easily programmed.

Let us describe the algorithm within the setting of a general message passing decoder, cf. Eq.Â (4.19). Given an integer ğ’©â‰«1much-greater-thanğ’©1{\cal N}\gg 1, one represent the messages distributions with two samples of size ğ’©ğ’©{\cal N}: ğ”“(t)={Î½1(t),â€¦,Î½ğ’©(t)}superscriptğ”“ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœˆ1ğ‘¡â€¦superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ’©ğ‘¡{\mathfrak{P}}^{(t)}=\{\nu_{1}^{(t)},\dots,\nu_{{\cal N}}^{(t)}\}, and ğ”“^(t)={Î½^1(t),â€¦,Î½^ğ’©(t)}superscript^ğ”“ğ‘¡superscriptsubscript^ğœˆ1ğ‘¡â€¦superscriptsubscript^ğœˆğ’©ğ‘¡\widehat{\mathfrak{P}}^{(t)}=\{\widehat{\nu}_{1}^{(t)},\dots,\widehat{\nu}_{{\cal N}}^{(t)}\}. Such samples are used as proxy for the corresponding distributions. For instance, one would approximate an expectation as

ğ”¼â€‹fâ€‹(Î½(t))â‰ˆ1ğ’©â€‹âˆ‘i=1ğ’©fâ€‹(Î½i(t)).ğ”¼ğ‘“superscriptğœˆğ‘¡1ğ’©superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ’©ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘¡ğ‘–\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}f(\nu^{(t)})\approx\frac{1}{{\cal N}}\sum_{i=1}^{{\cal N}}\,f(\nu^{(t)}_{i})\,. (4.24)

The populations are updated iteratively. In Fig.Â 15 we report the results of population dynamics simulations for two different LDPC ensembles, with respect to the BSC. We consider two performance measures: the bit error rate Pb(t)superscriptsubscriptPbğ‘¡{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)} and the bit conditional entropy H(t)superscriptğ»ğ‘¡H^{(t)}. The latter is defined as

H(t)=limNâ†’âˆ1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ”¼â€‹Hâ€‹(Xi|Î½Â¯i(t)),superscriptğ»ğ‘¡subscriptâ†’ğ‘1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ”¼ğ»conditionalsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğœˆğ‘–ğ‘¡\displaystyle H^{(t)}=\lim_{N\to\infty}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\mathbb{E}}\,H(X_{i}|\overline{\nu}_{i}^{(t)})\,, (4.25)

and encodes the uncertainty about bit xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} after tğ‘¡t BP iterations. It is intuitively clear that, as the algorithm progresses, the bit estimates improve and therefore Pb(t)superscriptsubscriptPbğ‘¡{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)} and H(t)superscriptğ»ğ‘¡H^{(t)} should be monotonically decreasing functions of the number of iterations. Further, they are expected to be monotonically increasing functions of the crossover probability pğ‘p. Both statement can be easily checked on the above plots, and can be proved rigorously as well.

Since Pb(t)superscriptsubscriptPbğ‘¡{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)} is non-negative and decreasing in tğ‘¡t, it has a finite limit

PbBPâ‰¡limtâ†’âˆPb(t),superscriptsubscriptPbBPsubscriptâ†’ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptPbğ‘¡\displaystyle{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}}\equiv\lim_{t\to\infty}{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)}\,, (4.26)

which is itself non-decreasing in pğ‘p. The limit curve PbBPsuperscriptsubscriptPbBP{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}} is estimated in Fig.Â 15 by choosing tğ‘¡t large enough so that Pb(t)superscriptsubscriptPbğ‘¡{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(t)} is independent of tğ‘¡t within the numerical accuracy.

Since PbBP=PbBPâ€‹(p)superscriptsubscriptPbBPsuperscriptsubscriptPbBPğ‘{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}}={\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}}(p) is a non-decreasing function of pğ‘p, one can define the BP threshold

pdâ‰¡sup{pâˆˆ[0,1/2]:PbBPâ€‹(p)=0}.subscriptğ‘dsupremumconditional-setğ‘012superscriptsubscriptPbBPğ‘0\displaystyle p_{\rm d}\equiv\sup\left\{\,p\in[0,1/2]\,:\,{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}}(p)=0\,\right\}\,. (4.27)

Analogous definitions can be provided for other channel families such as the BEC(Ïµ)italic-Ïµ(\epsilon). In general, the definition (4.27) can be extended to any family of BMS channels BMS(p)ğ‘(p) indexed by a real parameter pâˆˆIğ‘ğ¼p\in I, IâŠ†â„ğ¼â„I\subseteq{\mathbb{R}} being an interval (obviously the supsupremum\sup will be then taken over pâˆˆIğ‘ğ¼p\in I). The only condition is that the family is â€˜ordered by physical degradationâ€™. We shall not describe this concept formally, but limit ourselves to say that that pğ‘p should be an â€˜honestâ€™ noise parameter, in the sense that the channel worsen as pğ‘p increases.

Analytical upper and lower bounds can be derived for pdsubscriptğ‘dp_{\rm d}. In particular it can be shown that it is strictly larger than 00 (and smaller than 1/2121/2) for all LDPC ensembles with minimum variable degree at least 222. Numerical simulation of density evolution allows to determine it numerically with good accuracy. In Table 1 we report the results of a few such results.

Let us stress that the threshold pdsubscriptğ‘dp_{\rm d} has an important practical meaning. For any p<pdğ‘subscriptğ‘dp<p_{\rm d} one can achieve arbitrarily small bit error rate with high probability by just picking one random code from the ensemble LDPC and using BP decoding and running it for a large enough (but independent of the blocklength) number of iterations. For p>pdğ‘subscriptğ‘dp>p_{\rm d} the bit error rate is asymptotically lower bounded by PbBPâ€‹(p)>0superscriptsubscriptPbBPğ‘0{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{\mbox{\tiny BP}}(p)>0 for any fixed number of iterations. In principle it could be that after, letâ€™s say nasuperscriptğ‘›ğ‘n^{a}, a>0ğ‘0a>0 iterations a lower bit error rate is achieved. However simulations show quite convincingly that this is not the case.

In physics terms the algorithm undergoes a phase transition at pdsubscriptğ‘dp_{\rm d}. At first sight, such a phase transition may look entirely dependent on the algorithm definition and not â€˜universalâ€™ in any sense. As we will discuss in the next section, this is not the case. The phase transition at pdsubscriptğ‘dp_{\rm d} is somehow intrinsic to the underlying measure Î¼â€‹(xÂ¯)ğœ‡Â¯ğ‘¥\mu(\underline{x}), and has a well studied counterpart in the theory of mean field disordered spin models.

Apart from the particular channel family, the BP threshold depends on the particular code ensemble, i.e. (for the case considered here) on the code ensemble. It constitutes therefore a primary measure of the â€˜goodnessâ€™ of such a pair. Given a certain design rate Rğ‘…R, one would like to make pdsubscriptğ‘dp_{\rm d} as large as possible. This has motivated the introduction of code ensembles that generalize the regular ones studied here (starting from â€˜irregularâ€™ ones). Optimized ensembles have been shown to allow for exceptionally good performances. In the case of the erasure channel, they allowed to saturate Shannonâ€™s fundamental limit [27]. This is an important approach to the design of LDPC ensembles.

Let us finally mention that the BP threshold was defined in Eq.Â (4.27) in terms of the bit error rate. One may wonder whether a different performance parameter may yield a different threshold. As long as such parameter can be written in the form 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘ifâ€‹(hi(t))1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘¡\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}f(h_{i}^{(t)}) this is not the case. More precisely

pd=sup{pâˆˆI:h(t)â†’d+âˆ},subscriptğ‘dsupremumconditional-setğ‘ğ¼superscriptâ†’dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘¡\displaystyle p_{\rm d}=\sup\left\{\,p\in I\,:\,h^{(t)}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\rm d}}}{{\to}}+\infty\,\right\}\,, (4.28)

where, for the sake of generality we assumed the noise parameter to belong to an interval IâŠ†â„ğ¼â„I\subseteq{\mathbb{R}}. In other words, for any p<pdğ‘subscriptğ‘dp<p_{\rm d} the distribution of BP messages becomes a delta at plus infinity.

4.6 Belief Propagation versus MAP Decoding

So far we have seen that detailed predictions can be obtained for the performance of LDPC ensembles under message passing decoding (at least in the large blocklength limit). In particular the threshold noise for reliable communication is determined in terms of a distributional recursion (density evolution). This recursion can in turn be efficiently approximated numerically, leading to accurate predictions for the threshold.

It would be interesting to compare such predictions with the performances under optimal decoding strategies. Throughout this section we shall focus on symbol MAP decoding, which minimizes the bit error rate, and consider a generic channel family {BMSâ€‹(p)}BMSğ‘\{{\rm BMS}(p)\} ordered121212Such that the channel worsen as pğ‘p increases. Examples are the binary symmetric or binary erasure channels. by the noise parameter pğ‘p.

Given an LDPC ensemble, let Pb(N)superscriptsubscriptPbğ‘{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(N)} be the expected bit error rate when the blocklength is Nğ‘N. The MAP threshold pcsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm c} for such an ensemble can be defined as the largest (or, more precisely, the supremum) value of pğ‘p such that limNâ†’âˆPb(N)=0subscriptâ†’ğ‘superscriptsubscriptPbğ‘0\lim_{N\to\infty}{\rm P}_{{\rm b}}^{(N)}=0. In other words, for any p<pcğ‘subscriptğ‘cp<p_{\rm c} one can communicate with an arbitrarily small error probability, by using a random code from the ensemble, provided Nğ‘N is large enough.

By the optimality of MAP decoding, pdâ‰¤pcsubscriptğ‘dsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm d}\leq p_{\rm c}. In coding theory some techniques have been developed to prove upper and lower bounds on pcsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm c} [19, 52]. In particular it is easy to find ensembles for which there exist a gap between the two thresholds (namely pd<pcsubscriptğ‘dsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm d}<p_{\rm c} strictly). Consider for instance (k,l)ğ‘˜ğ‘™(k,l) regular ensembles with a fixed ratio l/k=1âˆ’Rğ‘™ğ‘˜1ğ‘…l/k=1-R. It is then possible to show that, as k,lâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘˜ğ‘™k,l\to\infty, the BP threshold goes to 00 while the MAP threshold approaches the Shannon limit.

This situation is somewhat unsatisfactory. The techniques used to estimate pdsubscriptğ‘dp_{\rm d} and pcsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm c} are completely different. This is puzzling since the two thresholds can be extremely close and even coincide for some ensembles. Furthermore, we know that pdâ‰¤pcsubscriptğ‘dsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm d}\leq p_{\rm c} by a general argument (optimality of MAP decoding), but this inequality is not â€˜built inâ€™ the corresponding derivations. Finally, it would be interesting to have a sharp estimate for pcsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm c}.

It turns out that a sharp characterization of pcsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm c} can be obtained through statistical mechanics techniques [42, 58, 38]. The statistical mechanics result has been proved to be a rigorous upper bound for general code ensembles, and it is conjectured to be tight [39, 35].

The starting point is to consider the conditional entropy of the channel input xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x} given the output yÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¦\underline{y}, HNâ€‹(XÂ¯|YÂ¯)subscriptğ»ğ‘conditionalÂ¯ğ‘‹Â¯ğ‘ŒH_{N}(\underline{X}|\underline{Y}). As shown in Eq.Â (2.18) this is given by the expectation of the log partition function appearing in Eq.Â (4.1) (apart from a trivial additive factor).

Let ğ–¿N=ğ”¼â€‹HNâ€‹(XÂ¯|YÂ¯)/Nsubscriptğ–¿ğ‘ğ”¼subscriptğ»ğ‘conditionalÂ¯ğ‘‹Â¯ğ‘Œğ‘{\sf f}_{N}={\mathbb{E}}H_{N}(\underline{X}|\underline{Y})/N denote the entropy density averaged over the code ensemble. Intuitively speaking, this quantity allows to estimate the typical number of inputs with non-negligible probability for a given channel output. If ğ–¿Nsubscriptğ–¿ğ‘{\sf f}_{N} is bounded away from 00 as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty, the typical channel output corresponds to an exponential number of (approximately) equally likely inputs. If on the other hand ğ–¿Nâ†’0â†’subscriptğ–¿ğ‘0{\sf f}_{N}\to 0, the correct input has to be searched among a sub-exponential number of candidates. This leads us to identify131313A rigorous justification of this identification can be obtained using Fanoâ€™s inequality. the MAP threshold as the largest noise level such that ğ–¿Nâ†’0â†’subscriptğ–¿ğ‘0{\sf f}_{N}\to 0 as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty.

The Bethe free energy provides a natural way to approximate log-partition functions on sparse graphs. It is known to be exact if the underlying graph is a tree and its stationary points are in correspondence with the fixed points of BP. In statistical physics terms, it is the correct variational formulation for the Bethe Peierls approximation. In random systems which are locally tree like, it is normally thought to provide the correct Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty limit unless long range correlations set in. These are in turn described through â€˜replica symmetry breakingâ€™ (see below).

As many mean field approximations, the Bethe approximation can be thought of as a way of writing the free energy as a function of a few correlation functions. It is natural to conjecture that the correct limit is obtained by optimizing the above lower bound, i.e.

In fact it is easy to show that, on the fixed point, the distributional equation h=dB+âˆ‘a=1lâˆ’1uasuperscriptdâ„ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘™1subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘h\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\rm d}}}{{=}}B+\sum_{a=1}^{l-1}u_{a} must be satisfied as well. In other words the couple uğ‘¢u, hâ„h must be a density evolution fixed point.

This conjecture has indeed been proved in the case of communication over the binary erasure channel for a large class of LDPC ensembles (including, for instance, regular ones).

The expression (4.37) is interesting because it bridges the analysis of BP and MAP decoding. For instance, it is immediate to show that it implies pdâ‰¤pcsubscriptğ‘dsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm d}\leq p_{\rm c}.

Evaluating the expression (4.37) implies an a priori infinite dimensional optimization problem. In practice good approximations can be obtained through the following procedure:

  1. 1.

    Initialize hâ„h, uğ‘¢u to a couple of symmetric random variables h(0)superscriptâ„0h^{(0)}, u(0)superscriptğ‘¢0u^{(0)}.

  2. 2.

    Implement numerically the density evolution recursion (4.20) and iterate it until an approximate fixed point is attained.

  3. 3.

    Evaluate the functional Ï•u,hsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¢â„\phi_{u,h} on such a fixed point, after enforcing u=datanhâ€‹{âˆi=1kâˆ’1tanhâ¡hi}superscriptdğ‘¢atanhsuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘˜1subscriptâ„ğ‘–u\stackrel{{\scriptstyle{\rm d}}}{{=}}{\rm atanh}\left\{\prod_{i=1}^{k-1}\tanh h_{i}\right\} exactly.

The above procedure can be repeated for several different initializations u(0)superscriptğ‘¢0u^{(0)}, h(0)superscriptâ„0h^{(0)}. The largest of the corresponding values of Ï•u,hsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¢â„\phi_{u,h} is then picked as an estimate for limNâ†’âˆğ–¿Nsubscriptâ†’ğ‘subscriptğ–¿ğ‘\lim_{N\to\infty}{\sf f}_{N}.

While his procedure is not guaranteed to exhaust all the possible density evolution fixed points, it allows to compute a sequence of lower bounds to the conditional entropy density. Further, one expects a small finite number of density evolution fixed points. In particular, for regular ensembles and p>pdğ‘subscriptğ‘dp>p_{\rm d}, a unique (stable) fixed point is expected to exist apart from the no-error one u,h=+âˆğ‘¢â„u,h=+\infty. In Table 2 we present the corresponding MAP thresholds for a few regular ensembles.

For further details on these results, and complete proofs, we refer to [39]. Here we limit ourselves to a brief discussion why the conjecture (4.37) is expected to hold from a statistical physics point of view.

The expression (4.37) corresponds to the â€˜replica symmetric ansatzâ€™ from the present problem. This usually breaks down if some form of long-range correlation (â€˜replica symmetry breakingâ€™) arises in the measure Î¼â€‹(â‹…)ğœ‡â‹…\mu(\,\cdot\,). This phenomenon is however not expected to happen in the case at hand. The technical reason is that the so-called Nishimori condition holds for Î¼â€‹(â‹…)ğœ‡â‹…\mu(\,\cdot\,) [38]. This condition generally holds for a large family of problems arising in communications and statistical inference. While Nishimori condition does not provide an easy proof of the conjecture (4.37), it implies a series of structural properties of Î¼â€‹(â‹…)ğœ‡â‹…\mu(\,\cdot\,) that are commonly regarded as incompatible with replica symmetry breaking.

Replica symmetry breaking is instead necessary to describe the structure of â€˜metastable statesâ€™ [17]. This can be loosely described as very deep local minima in the energy landscape introduced in SectionÂ 4.1. Here â€˜very deepâ€™ means that Î˜â€‹(N)Î˜ğ‘\Theta(N) bit flips are necessary to lower the energy (number of unsatisfied parity checks) when starting from such minima. As the noise level increases, such local minima become relevant at the so called â€˜dynamic phase transitionâ€™. It turns out that the critical noise for this phase transition coincides with the BP threshold pdsubscriptğ‘dp_{\rm d}. In other words the double phase transition at pdsubscriptğ‘dp_{\rm d} and pcsubscriptğ‘cp_{\rm c} is completely analogous to what happens in the mean field theory of structural glasses (see for instance Parisiâ€™s lectures at this School). Furthermore, this indicates that pdsubscriptğ‘dp_{\rm d} has a â€˜structuralâ€™ rather than purely algorithmic meaning.

Satisfiability, i.e., the problem of finding a solution to a satisfiability formula or proving that it is usatisfiable, is one of the prototypical NP-complete problems. Given a satisfiability formula, computing marginals with respect to the associated distribution Î¼â„±â€‹(â‹…)subscriptğœ‡â„±â‹…\mu_{{\cal F}}(\,\cdot\,) is relevant for tasks such as counting the number of solutions of â„±â„±{\cal F} or sampling them uniformly. These are well known ##\#-P complete problems.141414The notation ##\#-P refers to the hardness classification for counting problems.

The currently best algorithms for solving random instances for the Kğ¾K-SAT problem are based on a variant of BP, which is called survey propagation [11, 33, 11].

It is then possible to show that the couple (hÂ¯(t),hÂ¯(t))superscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘¡superscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘¡(\overline{h}^{(t)},\underline{h}^{(t)}) obeys a recursive distributional equation that, as mentioned, can be efficiently implemented numerically.

6 Belief Propagation Beyond the Binary Symmetric Channel

So far we have considered mainly the case of transmission over BMS channels, our reference example being the BSC. There are many other channel models that are important and are encountered in practical situations. Fortunately, it is relatively straightforward to extend the previous techniques and statements to a much larger class, and we review a few such instances in this section.

6.1 Binary Memoryless Symmetric Channels

In order to keep the notation simple, we assumed channel output to belong to a finite alphabet ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}. In our main example, the BSC, we had ğ’œ={ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}ğ’œ01{\cal A}=\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}. But in fact all results are valid for a wider class of binary memoryless symmetric (BMS) channels. One can prove that there is no loss of generality in assuming the output alphabet to be the real line â„â„{\mathbb{R}} (eventually completed with â„Â¯=â„âˆª{Â±âˆ}Â¯â„â„plus-or-minus\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}={\mathbb{R}}\cup\{\pm\infty\}).

Let yÂ¯=(y1,â€¦,yN)Â¯ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¦1â€¦subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘\underline{y}=(y_{1},\dots,y_{N}) be the vector of channel outputs on input xÂ¯=(x1,â€¦,xN)Â¯ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘\underline{x}=(x_{1},\dots,x_{N}). For a BMS the input is binary, i.e. xÂ¯âˆˆ{ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}NÂ¯ğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘\underline{x}\in\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N}. Further the channel is memoryless, i.e. the probability density of getting yÂ¯âˆˆâ„Â¯NÂ¯ğ‘¦superscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘\underline{y}\in\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}^{N} at output when the input is xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\underline{x}, is

Qâ€‹(yÂ¯|xÂ¯)ğ‘„conditionalÂ¯ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘¥\displaystyle Q(\underline{y}|\underline{x}) =âˆt=1NQâ€‹(yt|xt).absentsuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘¡1ğ‘ğ‘„conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡\displaystyle=\prod_{t=1}^{N}Q(y_{t}|x_{t}).

Finally, the symmetry property can be written without loss of generality, as Qâ€‹(yt|xt=ğŸ·)=Qâ€‹(âˆ’yt|xt=ğŸ¶)ğ‘„conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1ğ‘„conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡0Q(y_{t}|x_{t}={\tt 1})=Q(-y_{t}|x_{t}={\tt 0}).

One of the most important elements in this class is the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel, defined by

ytsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡\displaystyle y_{t} =xt+zt,tâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N},formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘§ğ‘¡ğ‘¡1â€¦ğ‘\displaystyle=x_{t}+z_{t}\,,\;\;\;\;\;\;t\in\{1,\dots,N\}\,,

where the sequence {zt}subscriptğ‘§ğ‘¡\{z_{t}\} is i.i.d. consisting of Gaussian random variables with mean zero and variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}. It is common in this setting to let xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} take values in {+1,âˆ’1}11\{+1,-1\} instead of {ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}01\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\} as we have assumed so far. The AWGNC transition probability density function is therefore

Qâ€‹(yt|xt)=12â€‹Ï€â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹eâˆ’(yâˆ’x)22â€‹Ïƒ2.ğ‘„conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡12ğœ‹superscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¥22superscriptğœ2\displaystyle Q(y_{t}|x_{t})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^{2}}}\;e^{-\frac{(y-x)^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}\,.

The AWGNC is the basic model of transmission of an electrical signal over a cable (here the noise is due to thermal noise in the receiver) and it is also a good model of a wireless channel in free space (e.g., transmission from a satellite).

Although the class of BMS channels is already fairly large, it is important in practice to go beyond it. The extension to the non-binary case is quite straightforward and so we will not discuss it in detail. The extension to channels with memory or the asymmetric case are more interesting and so we present them in the subsequent two sections.

6.2 Channels With Memory

Loosely speaking, in a memoryless channel the channel acts on each transmitted bit independently. In a channel with memory, on the other hand, the channel acts generally on the whole block of input bits together. An important special case of a channel with memory is if the channel can be modeled as a Markov chain, taking on a sequence of â€œchannel states.â€ Many physical channels posses this property and under this condition the message-passing approach can still be applied. For channels with memory there are two problems. First, we need to determine the capacity of the channel. Second, we need to devise efficient coding schemes that achieve rates close to this capacity. It turns out that both problems can be addressed in a fairly similar framework. Rather than discussing the general case we will look at a simple but typical example.

Let us start by computing the information rate/capacity of channels with memory, assuming that the channel has a Markov structure. As we discussed in SectionÂ 2.5 in the setting of BMS channels, the channel capacity can be expressed as the difference of two entropies, namely as Hâ€‹(X)âˆ’Hâ€‹(X|Y)ğ»ğ‘‹ğ»conditionalğ‘‹ğ‘ŒH(X)-H(X|Y). Here, Xğ‘‹X denotes the binary input and Yğ‘ŒY denotes the observation at the output of the channel whose input is Xğ‘‹X. Given two random variables Xğ‘‹X, Yğ‘ŒY, this entropy difference is called the mutual information and is typically denoted by Iâ€‹(X;Y)=Hâ€‹(X)âˆ’Hâ€‹(X;Y)ğ¼ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ»ğ‘‹ğ»ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒI(X;Y)=H(X)-H(X;Y).

A general channel, is defined by a channel transition probability Qâ€‹(y1N|x1N)ğ‘„conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¦1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘Q(y_{1}^{N}|x_{1}^{N}) (here and below x1Nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘x_{1}^{N} denotes the vector (x1,â€¦,xN)subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘(x_{1},\dots,x_{N})). In order to define a joint distribution of the input and output vectors, we have to prescribe a distribution on the channel input, call it pâ€‹(x1N)ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘p(x_{1}^{N}). The channel capacity is obtained by maximizing the mutual information over all possible distributions of the input, and eventually taking the Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty limit. In formulae

ğ™²â€‹(Q)=limNâ†’âˆsuppâ€‹(â‹…)Iâ€‹(X1N;Y1N)/N.ğ™²ğ‘„subscriptâ†’ğ‘subscriptsupremumğ‘â‹…ğ¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œ1ğ‘ğ‘\displaystyle{\tt C}(Q)=\lim_{N\to\infty}\sup_{p(\,\cdot\,)}\,I(X_{1}^{N};Y_{1}^{N})/N\,.

For BMS channels it is possible to show that the maximum occurs for the uniform prior: pâ€‹(x1N)=1/2Nğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘1superscript2ğ‘p(x_{1}^{N})=1/2^{N}. Under this distribution, Iâ€‹(X1N;Y1N)/Nğ¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œ1ğ‘ğ‘I(X_{1}^{N};Y_{1}^{N})/N is easily seen not to depend on Nğ‘N and we recover the expression in Sec.Â 2.5.

For channels with memory we have to maximize the mutual information over all possible distributions over {ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}Nsuperscript01ğ‘\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}^{N} (a space whose dimension is exponential in Nğ‘N), and take the limit Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty. An easier task is to choose a convenient input distribution pâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘â‹…p(\,\cdot\,) and then compute the corresponding mutual information in the Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty limit:

Iğ¼\displaystyle I =limNâ†’âˆIâ€‹(X1N;Y1N)/N.absentsubscriptâ†’ğ‘ğ¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘Œ1ğ‘ğ‘\displaystyle=\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}I(X_{1}^{N};Y_{1}^{N})/N\,. (6.1)

Remarkably, this quantity has an important operational meaning. It is the largest rate at which we can transmit reliably across the channel using a coding scheme such that the resulting input distribution matches pâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘â‹…p(\,\cdot\,).

To be definite, assume that the channel is defined by a state sequence {Ïƒt}tâ‰¥0subscriptsubscriptğœğ‘¡ğ‘¡0\{\sigma_{t}\}_{t\geq 0}, taking values in a finite alphabet, such that the joint probability distribution factors in the form

pâ€‹(x1n,y1n,Ïƒ0n)=pâ€‹(Ïƒ0)â€‹âˆi=1npâ€‹(xi,yi,Ïƒiâˆ£Ïƒiâˆ’1).ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ0ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğœ0superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–conditionalsubscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğœğ‘–1p(x_{1}^{n},y_{1}^{n},\sigma_{0}^{n})=p(\sigma_{0})\prod_{i=1}^{n}p(x_{i},y_{i},\sigma_{i}\mid\sigma_{i-1}). (6.2)

We will further assume that the transmitted bits (x1,â‹…,xN)subscriptğ‘¥1â‹…subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘(x_{1},\cdot,x_{N}) are iid uniform in {ğŸ¶,ğŸ·}01\{{\tt 0},{\tt 1}\}. The factor graph corresponding to (6.2) is shown in Fig.Â 17. It is drawn in a somewhat different way compared to the factor graphs we have seen so far. Note that in the standard factor graph corresponding to this factorization all variable nodes have degree two. In such a case it is convenient not to draw the factor graph as a bipartite graph but as a standard graph in which the nodes correspond to the factor nodes and the edges correspond to the variable nodes (which have degree two and therefore connect exactly two factors). Such a graphical representation is also known as normal graph or as Forney-style factor graph (FSFG), in honor of Dave Forney who introduced them [15].

Now that we can compute the maximal rate at which we can transmit reliably, let us consider coding. The symbol MAP decoder is

In words, the FSFG in Fig.Â 17 describes also the factorization for the message-passing decoder if we add to it the factor nodes describing the definition of the code. As always, this factor graph together with the initial messages stemming from the channel completely specify the message-passing rules, except for the message-passing schedule. Let us agree that we alternate one round of decoding with one round of channel estimation. No claim as to the optimality of this scheduling rule is made.

Notice that the correlations induced by the markovian structure of the channel are in general short ranged in time. This is analogous to what happens with a one-dimensional spin model, whose correlation length is always finite (at non-zero temperature). A good approximation to the above message passing schedule is therefore obtained by a â€˜windowedâ€™ decodes. This means that the state at time tğ‘¡t is estimated only of the basis of observations between time tâˆ’Rğ‘¡ğ‘…t-R and t+Rğ‘¡ğ‘…t+R, for some finite Rğ‘…R.

Assuming windowed decoding for channel estimation, it is not hard to show that after a fixed number of iterations, the decoding neighborhood is again asymptotically tree-like. In the case of the GEC the channel symmetry can be used to reduce to the all-zero codeword. Therefore, we can employ the technique of density evolution to determine thresholds and to optimize the ensembles.

  • Example 6:[GEC: State Estimation]

    For the case of transmission over the GEC the iterative decoder implicitly also estimates the state of the channel. Let us demonstrate this by means of the following example. We pick a GEC with three states. Let
